abstract.shortdesc: The euctl utility retrieves cloud state and allows cloud administrators to set cloud state. The state to be retrieved or set is described using a Management Information Base (MIB) style name, described as a dotted set of components. See usage notes and examples below.
abstract.note: The euctl command is intended to replace the deprecated euca-describe-properties and euca-modify-property commands.

section.title: Syntax
section.codeblock: euctl [-A] [-r] [-d] [-s] [-n] [-q] [--edit | --dump] [--format {json,yaml}] [-U URL] [--region USER@REGION] [-I KEY_ID] [-S KEY] [--security-token TOKEN] [--debug] [--debugger] [--version] [-h] [NAME[=VALUE|=@FILE] [NAME[=VALUE|=@FILE] ...]]

row.entry: List all the known variable names, including structures. Those with string or integer values will be output as usual; for the structured values, the methods of retrieving them are given.
Resets the named property to the default value.
Show variables' default values instead of their current values.
Show variables' descriptions instead of their current values.
Suppress output of the variable name. This is useful for setting shell variables.
Suppress all output when setting a variable. This option overrides the behavior of the -n parameter.

Edit a structured variable interactively. Only one variable may be edited per invocation. When looking for an editor, the program will first try the environment variable VISUAL, then the environment variable EDITOR, and finally the default editor, vi.
Output the value of a structured variable in its entirety.

Try to use the specified format when displaying a structured variable.
Valid values: json | yaml
Default value: json

When setting a variable, the MIB name should be followed by an equal sign and the new value:
To write variables using the contents of the files as their new values rather than typing them into the command line, follow them with =@ and those file names:
It is possible to read or write more than one variable in a single invocation of euctl. Just separate them with spaces:
section.codeblock: euctl one=1 two=2 three four=@4.txt five
section.p: In all of these cases, euctl will generally output each variable named on its command line, along with its current (and potentially just-changed) value. For example, the output of the command above could be: one = 1 two = 2 three = 3 four = 4 five = 5 To reset a variable to its default value, specify the -r option:

The information available from euctl consists of integers, strings, and structures. The structured information can only be retrieved by specialized programs and, in some cases, this program's --edit and --dump options.
